description: Late 14th century, from Old French transmutacion (“transformation, metamorphosis”), from Late Latin transmutationem, from Latin transmutare (“to change”).

entries.meaning: The conversion of one thing into something else; transformation.
(alchemy) Specifically, the supposed transformation of one element into another, especially of a base metal into gold.
examples: The transmutation of metals was secondary to the main aim, which was the spiritual transformation of the adept.

entries.meaning: (nuclear physics) The actual transformation of one element into another by a nuclear reaction.
